summary_llm:
The story of "Great Expectations" begins in a desolate Kentish churchyard on the marshes, where seven-year-old orphan Philip Pirrip, known as Pip, is visiting the graves of his parents and siblings. Suddenly, a fearsome escaped convict accosts him, threatening him and demanding food and a file. Terrified, Pip steals a pork pie and a file from his abusive older sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, and her kind, simple blacksmith husband, Joe, with whom he lives. He delivers the items to the convict, Abel Magwitch, who is hiding in the marshes.

The next day, soldiers arrive at the Gargery home, seeking two escaped convicts. Joe and Pip join the search party. They find Magwitch fighting another convict, Compeyson, in the marshes. Both are recaptured. Magwitch, to protect Pip, falsely confesses to stealing the food.

Soon after, Pip is summoned to Satis House, the decaying mansion of the eccentric, wealthy Miss Havisham, a jilted bride who lives in perpetual darkness amidst her untouched wedding feast, her clocks stopped at twenty minutes to nine. Miss Havisham wants Pip to "play" with her beautiful, cold, and haughty adopted daughter, Estella. Estella immediately makes Pip feel common and ashamed of his rough hands and boots. Despite her cruelty, Pip falls deeply in love with her and dreams of becoming a gentleman to win her affection. He continues to visit Satis House over several years, enduring Estella's taunts and Miss Havisham's strange lessons in breaking men's hearts.

Pip's sister, Mrs. Joe, is brutally attacked and left brain-damaged by an unknown assailant, who is later suggested to be Orlick, Joe's disgruntled journeyman. Biddy, a kind and intelligent girl from the local school, comes to live with them and care for Mrs. Joe. Pip is formally apprenticed to Joe as a blacksmith, a path he now despises, believing it is beneath him and will prevent him from ever being worthy of Estella. He confides his ambitions to Biddy, who sees through his snobbery.

One evening, Mr. Jaggers, a formidable London lawyer, visits Pip and announces that Pip has inherited a large fortune from an anonymous benefactor, on the condition that he immediately goes to London to be educated as a gentleman. Pip is to be known as "Pip" and must never inquire about the benefactor's identity. Pip, overjoyed, assumes Miss Havisham is his secret patron and that he is destined to marry Estella. He bids a somewhat condescending farewell to Joe and Biddy, feeling a mix of guilt and relief as he leaves his humble life behind.

In London, Pip rooms with Herbert Pocket, a cheerful and kind young man whom Pip recognizes as the "pale young gentleman" he once fought at Satis House. They become close friends. Herbert is Miss Havisham's cousin and tutors Pip in gentlemanly manners. Pip also meets Jaggers' eccentric clerk, Wemmick, who maintains a strict professional demeanor at work but transforms into a warm, jovial man at his home in Walworth, where he cares for his deaf "Aged Parent." Pip observes Jaggers' strange household, particularly his housekeeper, Molly, a strong-wristed woman with a troubled past.

Joe visits Pip in London, but Pip is embarrassed by Joe's simple manners and commonness, treating him coldly. Joe, sensing Pip's change, leaves after delivering a message from Miss Havisham. Pip feels immense guilt. Pip lives extravagantly, accumulating debt with Herbert, but secretly arranges for Herbert to get a position with Clarriker & Co. through Wemmick.

Estella returns to London, now a stunning young woman, and Pip's love for her intensifies. However, she remains cold and warns him that she has no heart. She is being "shown" around by Miss Havisham to attract wealthy suitors. Pip despises Bentley Drummle, a coarse and unpleasant man who courts Estella, but she seems to encourage him. Pip confronts Miss Havisham, believing she is grooming him for Estella, and she encourages his belief without confirming it. Estella eventually announces her intention to marry Drummle, breaking Pip's heart.

On a stormy night, Pip's world shatters. His true benefactor arrives: Abel Magwitch, the convict from the marshes. Pip is horrified to learn that his "great expectations" come from a criminal, not Miss Havisham. Magwitch, now a wealthy sheep farmer in Australia, explains he dedicated his life to making Pip a gentleman as thanks for Pip's kindness years ago. He is a transported convict, and his return to England means a death sentence. Magwitch also reveals his past with Compeyson, the other convict, who was a gentleman swindler who betrayed Magwitch and received a lighter sentence. Compeyson is now in London and poses a threat.

Pip's disillusionment is profound, but he feels a growing sense of responsibility and loyalty to Magwitch. He confides in Herbert, who remains loyal and helps him plan Magwitch's escape.

Pip learns more secrets. Jaggers reveals to Pip and Wemmick that Molly, his housekeeper, is Estella's mother. She was tried for murder (of a woman who was Compeyson's lover and had a child with Magwitch) but acquitted, with Jaggers as her defense lawyer. Pip realizes Estella is the daughter of Magwitch and Molly. He confronts Miss Havisham, revealing Magwitch is his benefactor and that she misled him. He also tells her about Estella's marriage to Drummle. Miss Havisham is filled with remorse, realizing the pain she caused. Later, while sitting by the fire, her dress catches fire. Pip saves her, severely burning his hands, but she dies weeks later, having left most of her fortune to Estella.

Pip, Herbert, and Startop (a friend from Matthew Pocket's tutelage) plan to smuggle Magwitch out of the country by boat. During the escape attempt on the Thames, Compeyson appears, having been shadowing Magwitch. In a struggle, both men fall into the water. Compeyson drowns, but Magwitch is severely injured and recaptured.

Magwitch is tried and sentenced to death. Pip remains loyal, visiting him in prison and holding his hand. Magwitch dies peacefully before his execution, having learned from Pip that his daughter, Estella, is alive and a lady. Pip tells him he loves Estella.

Overwhelmed by stress and grief, Pip falls gravely ill with a fever and is deep in debt. Joe comes to London and nurses him back to health, paying off his debts. Pip finally realizes Joe's true worth and kindness. He decides to return to the forge to ask Biddy to marry him, hoping to atone for his past snobbery. However, upon arriving, he finds that Joe and Biddy have married. Pip is genuinely happy for them, having shed his old pride.

Pip then joins Herbert and Startop in their merchant business in Cairo, working hard and honestly. He becomes a successful merchant.

Eleven years later, Pip returns to England and visits the ruins of Satis House. He finds Estella there. Drummle is dead, and Estella has suffered greatly, which has softened her. They walk away hand-in-hand, and Pip expresses hope that they will "never part again."

This is a key revelation that ties together several plot threads. (Major omission).
7.  **Miss Havisham's explicit revenge motive and Pip being "practice":** The original states Miss Havisham raised Estella "as revenge" and that "Pip was merely a boy for the young Estella to practice on." The generated summary mentions her "strange lessons in breaking men's hearts" but doesn't explicitly state the revenge motive or Pip's role as practice. The generated summary states she "dies weeks later." This changes the immediate outcome and the duration of her suffering/repentance. (Significant difference in detail).
10. **Orlick's attempt to murder Pip:** The original includes a dramatic scene where Orlick lures Pip to the marshes and attempts to kill him, only for Herbert to intervene and save Pip. This entire significant event is missing from the generated summary. (Major omission).
11. **Pip losing his fortune:** The original explicitly states, "Pip loses his fortune" after Magwitch's sentencing. The generated summary implies Pip's financial distress through debt but doesn't explicitly state the loss of the fortune itself. (Minor omission).
12. **Specific details from Joe's news from home:** The original lists that Orlick was jailed after robbing Pumblechook, and Biddy taught Joe to read and write. These specific pieces of news are omitted from the generated summary. (Minor omissions of specific outcomes).
13. **Beneficiary of Miss Havisham's will:** The original states Miss Havisham "left most of her fortune to the Pockets." The generated summary states she "left most of her fortune to Estella." This is a factual discrepancy. (Major factual error).

**Extra Details in Generated Summary (compared to Original):**

1.  **Specifics of Pip's theft for Magwitch:** The generated summary adds that Pip steals a "pork pie" from his "abusive older sister." (Minor extra detail, adds color).

summary_llm:
The plot of William Shakespeare's "Hamlet" unfolds in Elsinore Castle, Denmark, following the recent death of King Hamlet and the hasty marriage of his widow, Queen Gertrude, to his brother, Claudius, who has now assumed the throne.

**Act I**
The play opens on the castle ramparts, where guards Barnardo and Marcellus, along with Hamlet's friend Horatio, witness the ghost of the recently deceased King Hamlet. They decide to inform Prince Hamlet.

Inside the castle, King Claudius addresses his court, announcing his marriage to Gertrude and his ascension. He dispatches ambassadors to Norway to address a potential threat from young Fortinbras, who seeks to reclaim lands lost by his father to the elder King Hamlet. Claudius grants Laertes, son of the Lord Chamberlain Polonius, permission to return to France, but denies Hamlet's request to return to Wittenberg. Hamlet, still deeply grieving his father and disgusted by his mother's quick marriage, expresses his sorrow in a soliloquy.

Horatio, Marcellus, and Barnardo tell Hamlet about the ghost. Hamlet agrees to join them that night.

Before Laertes departs for France, his father Polonius gives him lengthy advice on how to conduct himself. Polonius then warns his daughter Ophelia against Hamlet's romantic advances, believing them to be insincere and politically motivated, and orders her to reject him. Ophelia, obedient, agrees.

That night, on the ramparts, the Ghost appears to Hamlet, beckoning him to follow alone. Despite the warnings of Horatio and Marcellus, Hamlet follows. The Ghost reveals that it is indeed King Hamlet's spirit, trapped in purgatory, and that he was not killed by a snake bite as publicly believed, but murdered by Claudius, who poured poison into his ear while he slept. The Ghost demands that Hamlet avenge his "most foul, strange, and unnatural murder" but warns him not to harm his mother, leaving her judgment to heaven. Hamlet is horrified and vows revenge. He makes Horatio and Marcellus swear on his sword not to reveal what they have seen, and tells them he may feign madness ("put an antic disposition on") to further his plans.

**Act II**
Polonius sends his servant Reynaldo to Paris to subtly spy on Laertes. Ophelia, distressed, reports to Polonius that Hamlet came to her looking disheveled, staring at her intensely without speaking. Polonius concludes that Hamlet's madness is a result of Ophelia's rejection of his love, as he had commanded. He decides to inform the King.

King Claudius and Queen Gertrude, concerned by Hamlet's melancholy, summon his childhood friends, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, to discover the cause of his behavior. Polonius presents his theory to the King and Queen, suggesting they observe an encounter between Hamlet and Ophelia to test it.

Hamlet, feigning madness, engages in witty but nonsensical banter with Polonius. He quickly sees through Rosencrantz and Guildenstern's pretense, deducing they were sent by the King and Queen. He expresses his disillusionment with the world.

A troupe of traveling actors arrives at Elsinore. Hamlet, delighted, welcomes them and asks them to perform "The Murder of Gonzago," a play with a plot similar to his father's murder. He plans to insert a short speech he will write into the play, hoping to "catch the conscience of the King" by observing Claudius's reaction. In a soliloquy, Hamlet chastises himself for his inaction and resolves to use the play as his test.

**Act III**
Rosencrantz and Guildenstern report to the King and Queen that they could not discover the cause of Hamlet's madness, but that Hamlet is interested in the play. Claudius and Polonius then set their trap: they instruct Ophelia to walk in the lobby while they hide and observe Hamlet's interaction with her.

Hamlet enters, delivering his famous "To be, or not to be" soliloquy, contemplating suicide and the fear of the unknown after death. He then encounters Ophelia in the "nunnery scene." He denies ever loving her, tells her to go to a nunnery, and makes harsh, misogynistic remarks about women and marriage, seemingly aware that they are being observed. Claudius, observing, concludes that Hamlet's madness is not due to love but something more dangerous. He decides to send Hamlet to England, ostensibly to collect an overdue tribute, but actually to get rid of him. Polonius, still convinced of the love theory, suggests one more attempt to observe Hamlet with his mother.

Hamlet gives the actors detailed instructions on how to perform naturally. During the performance of "The Mousetrap" (Hamlet's modified "The Murder of Gonzago"), the player-king is poisoned in the ear by his nephew. Claudius, visibly disturbed, rises abruptly, calls for lights, and rushes out, confirming his guilt to Hamlet and Horatio.

Hamlet is ecstatic. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern arrive to tell him the King is displeased and the Queen wants to speak with him. Polonius also conveys the Queen's message. Hamlet, now resolved, makes a dark soliloquy about his readiness for violence.

Claudius, alone, attempts to pray and confess his guilt, but finds he cannot truly repent because he still possesses the fruits of his crime: his crown and his queen. Hamlet enters, sees Claudius praying, and decides *not* to kill him then, believing that killing him while he is confessing would send him to heaven, which would not be proper revenge for his father's murder. He decides to wait for a time when Claudius is engaged in a sinful act.

In Gertrude's private chamber (the "closet scene"), Hamlet confronts his mother. Polonius hides behind an arras (tapestry) to eavesdrop. Hamlet fiercely denounces Gertrude's marriage to Claudius. When Gertrude cries for help, Polonius echoes her cry. Hamlet, thinking it is Claudius, stabs through the arras, killing Polonius. Hamlet continues to berate his mother, contrasting his father's noble image with Claudius's villainy. The Ghost appears (visible only to Hamlet), reminding him of his purpose and to comfort his mother. Gertrude, seeing Hamlet speak to empty air, believes him truly mad. Hamlet reveals he knows he is being sent to England and tells her not to sleep with Claudius. He then drags Polonius's body away.

**Act IV**
Gertrude reports to Claudius that Hamlet, in his madness, has killed Polonius. Claudius realizes the danger to himself and orders Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to find Hamlet and Polonius's body. He decides Hamlet must be sent to England immediately. Hamlet refuses to tell Rosencrantz and Guildenstern where the body is, engaging in cryptic wordplay. He is brought before Claudius, reveals Polonius's body is "at supper" (being eaten by worms) and eventually says it's under the stairs to the lobby. Claudius tells him he must go to England. Hamlet departs, making pointed remarks. Claudius reveals in a soliloquy that he has sent letters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern to the King of England, ordering Hamlet's execution upon arrival.

On his way to the ship, Hamlet encounters Fortinbras's army marching through Denmark to fight for a small, worthless piece of land in Poland. In a soliloquy, Hamlet contrasts Fortinbras's decisive action for a trivial cause with his own inaction despite a great cause, resolving to focus only on bloody revenge.

Back at Elsinore, Gertrude and Horatio witness Ophelia, who has gone mad with grief over her father's death and Hamlet's departure. She sings fragmented, sorrowful, and sometimes lewd songs. Laertes bursts into the castle with a mob, demanding answers about his father's death and a proper burial. Claudius calms him, promising to explain everything and help him get revenge. Ophelia enters, still mad, distributing symbolic flowers, which further devastates Laertes.

Sailors deliver a letter from Hamlet to Horatio. Hamlet explains that his ship was attacked by pirates, he boarded their vessel, and they treated him well in exchange for a favor, returning him to Denmark. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are still on their way to England.

Claudius and Laertes plot Hamlet's death. They devise a fencing match where Laertes will use an unblunted, poisoned rapier. As a backup, Claudius will prepare a poisoned drink for Hamlet. Gertrude enters and reports that Ophelia has drowned, describing her falling from a willow tree into a brook while making garlands, and floating for a while before sinking. Laertes is overcome with grief.

**Act V**
Two gravediggers are preparing Ophelia's grave, debating whether she deserves a Christian burial given the suspicious circumstances of her death. Hamlet and Horatio arrive and engage in philosophical banter with the first gravedigger, who unearths Yorick's skull, the former court jester known to Hamlet. Hamlet reflects on mortality.

A funeral procession arrives for Ophelia, but it is a "maimed rite" (lacking full Christian ceremony) due to the suspected suicide. Laertes is furious at the priest's refusal to grant her more rites. Hamlet realizes it's Ophelia's funeral. Laertes leaps into the grave, expressing his overwhelming grief. Hamlet, also overcome, reveals himself, leaps into the grave as well, and grapples with Laertes, claiming he loved Ophelia more. They are separated. Claudius tells Laertes to be patient and remember their plan.

Hamlet tells Horatio how he discovered Claudius's plot: he secretly read the letter Rosencrantz and Guildenstern carried, which ordered his execution. He replaced it with a forged letter ordering the execution of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. He expresses no regret for their fate. He feels he has a just cause to kill Claudius.

Osric, a foppish courtier, arrives to invite Hamlet to the fencing match with Laertes. Hamlet mocks Osric. Hamlet has a bad feeling but decides to go through with the match, accepting that "the readiness is all."

The court gathers for the fencing match. Claudius places the poisoned drink (a "union" pearl) on the table. Hamlet and Laertes begin. Hamlet scores the first hit. Claudius offers Hamlet the poisoned drink, but Hamlet declines, saying he'll drink after the next hit. Hamlet scores a second hit. Gertrude, unaware of the poison, drinks from the cup to toast Hamlet. Claudius tries to stop her but fails. Laertes, enraged, takes his opportunity. In a scuffle, he wounds Hamlet with the poisoned rapier. They grapple, and Hamlet disarms Laertes, then wounds Laertes with Laertes' *own* poisoned rapier.

Gertrude collapses, crying "O, my dear Hamlet, the drink, the drink! I am poisoned." She dies. Laertes, dying, confesses the entire plot to Hamlet, revealing the poisoned rapier and the poisoned drink, and blaming Claudius. Hamlet, furious and dying, stabs Claudius with the poisoned rapier and forces him to drink the rest of the poisoned wine. Claudius dies. Laertes dies, asking for Hamlet's forgiveness.

Hamlet, dying, prevents Horatio from drinking the poison, asking him to live and tell his story. He names Fortinbras as his successor to the Danish throne. Hamlet dies.

Fortinbras arrives with his army, having returned from Poland. English ambassadors also arrive, announcing that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern have been executed as per the forged letter. Horatio promises to explain the entire tragic story. Fortinbras, seeing the carnage, takes charge and orders a military funeral for Hamlet, acknowledging him as a prince who would have been a great king.

summary_llm:
Here is a very detailed summary of the plot for Charlotte Brontë's "Jane Eyre":

The story begins with Jane Eyre, a plain, intelligent, and spirited orphan girl, living with her wealthy aunt, Mrs. Reed, and her three cousins, Eliza, Georgiana, and John, at Gateshead Hall. Jane is constantly mistreated by Mrs. Reed, who resents her presence, and cruelly bullied by her cousins, especially the vicious John Reed. One day, after John strikes her, Jane retaliates, leading to her being locked in the Red-room, a haunted chamber where her deceased uncle, Mr. Reed, died. Overwhelmed by fear and a sense of injustice, Jane faints.

Following this incident, an apothecary named Mr. Lloyd suggests that Jane be sent to school. Mrs. Reed, eager to be rid of her, agrees. Jane is sent to Lowood Institution, a charity school for orphaned girls. The conditions at Lowood are harsh: the food is meager, the rooms are cold, and the girls are subjected to strict discipline by the hypocritical and cruel superintendent, Mr. Brocklehurst, who preaches asceticism while his own family lives in luxury.

At Lowood, Jane finds her first true friend in Helen Burns, a gentle, pious, and intelligent girl who endures suffering with stoic patience and Christian faith. Jane also finds a kind mentor in Miss Temple, the superintendent, who offers her warmth and intellectual stimulation. Mr. Brocklehurst publicly humiliates Jane by accusing her of lying, but Miss Temple clears her name. A typhus epidemic sweeps through Lowood, killing many girls, including Helen Burns, who dies peacefully in Jane's arms. After the epidemic, public outcry leads to improved conditions at the school. Jane remains at Lowood for eight years, six as a student and two as a teacher.

When Miss Temple marries and leaves Lowood, Jane feels a renewed longing for a wider world and advertises for a governess position. She receives an offer from Thornfield Hall and accepts. Upon her arrival, she is greeted by Mrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, whom Jane initially mistakes for the owner. Jane's charge is a young French girl named Adèle Varens. Thornfield Hall is a large, old, and somewhat mysterious house, and Jane occasionally hears strange laughter and sounds emanating from the third floor.

The master of Thornfield, Mr. Edward Fairfax Rochester, soon returns. He is a brooding, passionate, and enigmatic man, older than Jane, with a dark past. Jane and Mr. Rochester develop an unusual relationship, engaging in long, intense conversations that reveal their intellectual compatibility and Jane's strong spirit. Jane finds herself increasingly drawn to Rochester, despite his abrupt manner and her awareness of their social differences. During this time, Jane saves Rochester from a mysterious fire in his bed, which he dismisses as the work of a drunken servant named Grace Poole, though Jane suspects there is more to the story.

Rochester frequently teases Jane and tries to make her jealous by inviting a party of wealthy, aristocratic guests to Thornfield, including the beautiful and superficial Blanche Ingram, whom he appears to court. Jane observes their interactions, feeling a deep sadness but maintaining her composure. Another mysterious incident occurs when a visitor, Richard Mason, is attacked and stabbed during the night. Jane is tasked with tending to his wounds while Rochester maintains secrecy about the event.

Jane receives a letter informing her that Mrs. Reed is dying and wishes to see her. Jane returns to Gateshead, where she finds Mrs. Reed on her deathbed. Mrs. Reed confesses her lifelong resentment towards Jane and reveals that Jane's uncle, Mr. John Eyre, had written to her three years prior, expressing his desire to adopt Jane and leave her his fortune, but Mrs. Reed had falsely replied that Jane had died. Jane forgives Mrs. Reed, who dies shortly after.

Upon her return to Thornfield, Rochester proposes marriage to Jane under a chestnut tree. Despite her initial disbelief and the vast social chasm between them, Jane accepts, deeply in love. As the wedding day approaches, Jane experiences unsettling events: a mysterious woman tears her wedding veil and appears in her room one night, which Rochester again dismisses as a dream or Grace Poole's doing.

On the wedding day, at the altar, the ceremony is interrupted by a solicitor, Mr. Briggs, and Richard Mason. They reveal that Mr. Rochester is already married. His wife, Bertha Mason, is alive and living in Thornfield Hall. Rochester, in a desperate attempt to explain, takes Jane and the others to the third floor, where he reveals his wife: a violent, insane woman, kept locked away for years due to her madness, which runs in her family. Rochester explains his forced marriage to Bertha for her wealth, her subsequent descent into madness, and his desperate search for love and happiness, which led him to Jane. He pleads with Jane to stay with him as his mistress.

Devastated but firm in her moral principles, Jane refuses to become Rochester's mistress. Despite her profound love for him, she believes it would compromise her integrity and self-respect. In the middle of the night, with no money or possessions, Jane flees Thornfield Hall, leaving Rochester behind.

Jane wanders for days, destitute and starving, eventually collapsing on the doorstep of Moor House, the home of the Rivers family. She is taken in by the kind sisters, Diana and Mary Rivers, and their brother, St. John Rivers, a cold, devout, and ambitious clergyman. Jane, using the assumed name "Jane Elliott," recovers her health and finds peace. St. John finds her a job as a village schoolmistress in Morton.

St. John, discovering Jane's true identity, reveals that her uncle, Mr. John Eyre, has died and left his entire fortune of 20,000 pounds to her. He further reveals that he, Diana, and Mary are Jane's cousins, as John Eyre was also their uncle. Jane, overjoyed to have family, insists on sharing her inheritance equally with her cousins, ensuring their financial security.

St. John, driven by his missionary zeal, proposes marriage to Jane, not out of love, but because he believes she would be a suitable and dedicated missionary wife to accompany him to India. Jane struggles with his proposal; she respects his piety but cannot marry without love and fears that her spirit would be crushed under his austere will. She almost succumbs to his powerful persuasion, but then, in a moment of spiritual clarity, she believes she hears Rochester's voice calling her name.

Convinced she must find out what happened to Rochester, Jane leaves Moor House and returns to Thornfield. She finds the hall a burnt-out ruin. An innkeeper tells her that Bertha Mason set the house on fire and died by jumping from the battlements. Rochester, in his attempt to save Bertha and the servants, was blinded and lost a hand. He is now living in seclusion at Ferndean, a remote lodge, with two old servants.

Jane goes to Ferndean and finds Rochester, broken and despairing. Their reunion is emotional and heartfelt. Jane proposes to him, and they marry. Slowly, Rochester regains partial sight in one eye, enough to see their firstborn son.

The novel concludes with Jane stating that she and Rochester have been married for ten years and are perfectly happy. Diana and Mary are happily married, and St. John is still in India, dedicating his life to God's work, awaiting his heavenly reward. Jane affirms her deep, enduring love for Rochester, describing him as "flesh of my flesh; and bone of my bone."

summary_llm:
The story begins by introducing Charles Bovary, a clumsy, unremarkable boy who struggles through his schooling. His ambitious mother pushes him into studying medicine, and he eventually becomes an "officier de santé" (a lower-grade doctor). His mother then arranges his marriage to Héloïse Dubuc, an older, wealthy widow, believing it will secure his future. Charles establishes his practice in the small town of Tostes.

One day, Charles is called to a farm to set the broken leg of Monsieur Rouault. There, he meets Emma Rouault, the farmer's beautiful, convent-educated daughter. Emma is bored with her rustic life, having filled her head with romantic ideals from novels. Charles is immediately smitten by her beauty and grace. He begins to visit the farm frequently, ostensibly to check on Monsieur Rouault, but primarily to see Emma.

Héloïse, Charles's wife, grows suspicious and jealous. Shortly after, she dies suddenly, leaving Charles a widower. It is later revealed that Héloïse was not wealthy at all, but had hidden significant debts from Charles. After a period of mourning, Charles begins to openly court Emma. Monsieur Rouault, seeing Charles as a respectable match, gives his consent.

Charles and Emma marry. Emma, expecting a grand, passionate, and luxurious life like those in her novels, is immediately disillusioned. The wedding is a simple country affair, and Charles is a kind but dull and unimaginative husband. Her dreams of a romantic existence quickly clash with the mundane reality of her marriage and life in Tostes.

Emma tries to make their home more elegant, but Tostes offers no escape from her boredom. Her only taste of the high society she craves comes when she and Charles are invited to a ball at the Marquis d'Andervilliers' château, La Vaubyessard. The opulence, the elegant people, and the refined atmosphere leave a profound impression on her, intensifying her longing for a life of luxury and passion. After the ball, she falls into a deep depression, becoming restless and prone to "nervous attacks." Charles, worried about her health, decides they need a change of scenery and moves his practice to the larger market town of Yonville-l'Abbaye.

In Yonville, Emma and Charles meet a new cast of characters: Homais, the pompous, anti-clerical pharmacist; Léon Dupuis, a young, romantic law clerk who shares Emma's artistic sensibilities and dreams; Monsieur Lheureux, a manipulative merchant who preys on people's desires; Bournisien, the local curé; and Hippolyte, the club-footed stable boy. Emma soon becomes pregnant.

Emma gives birth to a daughter, Berthe, but is disappointed it's not a boy. She shows little maternal affection, preferring to dream of her own romantic fantasies. She develops a platonic, intellectual infatuation with Léon. They spend hours discussing poetry, art, and their shared longing for a more exciting life. However, Emma, still clinging to a sense of propriety, resists any physical intimacy. Léon, frustrated by her indecision and his own lack of prospects in Yonville, eventually leaves for Paris to study law. Emma is devastated by his departure, feeling more alone and unfulfilled than ever.

Emma falls into a deep depression after Léon leaves. Her spirits are lifted by the arrival of Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy, cynical landowner and notorious womanizer. Rodolphe, seeing Emma's beauty and vulnerability, decides to seduce her. He courts her with lavish flattery, small gifts, and passionate declarations, appealing directly to her romantic ideals. Emma, starved for affection and excitement, quickly falls completely for him, believing him to be the true love she has always dreamed of.

Their affair begins, with secret meetings in the woods and at Rodolphe's estate. Emma is completely consumed, neglecting her daughter and her wifely duties. She takes increasing risks, driven by her passion. She also begins to spend money on clothes and gifts, trying to make herself more alluring for Rodolphe. Charles remains oblivious, attributing Emma's renewed vivacity to her improved health.

Homais, eager for local fame, convinces Charles to attempt a "revolutionary" surgical procedure to cure Hippolyte's clubfoot. Charles, hoping to impress Emma and prove his competence, agrees. The operation is a disaster; Hippolyte develops gangrene, and his leg must be amputated by another doctor. Emma is disgusted by Charles's incompetence and feels humiliated by his failure, which further pushes her into Rodolphe's arms.

Emma, completely infatuated, plans to elope with Rodolphe, believing they will start a new life of passion and adventure together. Rodolphe, however, is bored with the affair and unwilling to commit. He writes a cruel breakup letter, delivered to Emma in a basket of apricots, and leaves Yonville. Emma is utterly shattered by his betrayal. She suffers a severe nervous breakdown, falling gravely ill and nearly dying. Charles, devoted and still oblivious to the affair, nurses her back to health, incurring significant debt in the process.

After her recovery, Emma attempts to find solace in religion, but her newfound piety is short-lived. She remains restless and unhappy, her life feeling empty.

Some time later, Charles and Emma attend the opera in Rouen (Lucia di Lammermoor). There, they encounter Léon, who has returned from Paris a more sophisticated and confident young man. Léon, no longer timid, is captivated by Emma's beauty and renewed vivacity. They begin to meet secretly in Rouen, where Emma invents excuses (music lessons, shopping trips) to visit.

Emma and Léon begin an affair. This affair is less about idealized romance and more about passion and the luxurious lifestyle she craves. Emma begins to borrow heavily from Lheureux, the merchant, to fund her expensive tastes – lavish clothes, gifts for Léon, and indulgent meals and hotel rooms in Rouen. Lheureux, seeing an opportunity, encourages her spending, offering loans at exorbitant interest rates. Emma, desperate for money, even forges Charles's signature on promissory notes.

Emma's debts spiral out of control. Lheureux presses her for payment, and she desperately tries to raise money, selling off furniture and small items. She attempts to borrow from Léon (who has little money), Homais (who refuses), Bournisien (who misunderstands her pleas), and even the notary Guillaumin (who makes an indecent proposal).

A court judgment is issued against the Bovarys, and their property is to be seized. In a final, desperate attempt, Emma goes to Rodolphe, begging him for money. Rodolphe, though wealthy, coldly refuses to help, claiming he has no ready cash and is annoyed by her persistence. Emma is utterly crushed by his indifference.

Driven to despair, humiliation, and ruin, Emma returns to Yonville. She goes to Homais's laboratory, steals a bottle of arsenic, and swallows it. She suffers a terrible, agonizing death, witnessed by Charles, Homais, and Bournisien. Her final moments are filled with physical torment and a grotesque vision of the blind beggar she had previously encountered.

Charles is heartbroken and bewildered by Emma's death. He still doesn't fully understand her. He later discovers her love letters from Rodolphe and Léon, and her financial papers, which reveal the full extent of her affairs and debts. He is devastated by the truth, but his love for her remains, tinged with a pathetic understanding. He tries to pay off her debts, selling off everything they own. He becomes a recluse, neglects his medical practice, and grows increasingly poor. He eventually encounters Rodolphe and, instead of anger, expresses a resigned understanding: "It was fate."

Charles dies alone in his garden, clutching a lock of Emma's hair. Their daughter, Berthe, is sent to live with her impoverished grandmother, who soon dies, and Berthe is then sent to work in a cotton mill. Homais, the pharmacist, thrives, receives the Legion of Honor, and continues his pompous, self-serving life. Léon marries and lives a respectable life. Lheureux continues his predatory business practices.

summary_llm:
The novel "Mrs. Dalloway" chronicles a single day in June 1923, primarily following Clarissa Dalloway, a high-society woman in London, as she prepares for a party she is hosting that evening, and Septimus Warren Smith, a shell-shocked World War I veteran, whose mental health is rapidly deteriorating.

The day begins with Clarissa Dalloway, at fifty-one years old, leaving her Westminster home to buy flowers for her party. As she walks through Bond Street, she reflects on her youth, her decision to marry Richard Dalloway instead of the more passionate Peter Walsh, and her deep affection for her old friend Sally Seton. She enjoys the vibrant atmosphere of London and feels a profound connection to the city. She briefly encounters Hugh Whitbread, a somewhat pompous old acquaintance, whom she finds tiresome.

Meanwhile, Septimus Warren Smith, a veteran suffering from severe post-traumatic stress disorder, is in Regent's Park with his young Italian wife, Lucrezia, known as Rezia. Septimus is tormented by hallucinations, seeing his dead friend Evans and believing that trees are speaking to him. He feels utterly alone and persecuted, while Rezia is desperate and exhausted by his condition, longing for him to recover. They are on their way to see Sir William Bradshaw, a prominent psychiatrist.

Back at Clarissa's house, her old suitor, Peter Walsh, unexpectedly arrives from India. He has returned to London to arrange a divorce for his current love interest, Daisy. His visit to Clarissa is charged with unspoken history and regret. They discuss their past, Clarissa's choice to marry Richard, and Peter's own complicated life. Peter, still deeply affected by Clarissa, leaves feeling a mix of old affection, resentment, and a sense of his own failures. He wanders through London, observing people and reflecting on his life.

Septimus and Rezia attend their appointment with Sir William Bradshaw. Bradshaw, cold and clinical, quickly diagnoses Septimus with a "lack of proportion" and recommends that he be separated from Rezia and sent to a mental institution in the country for a complete rest cure. Septimus is terrified by the prospect, feeling that his soul is being invaded, while Rezia is devastated but sees no other option. They leave the consultation feeling hopeless and trapped.

Clarissa's husband, Richard Dalloway, a Member of Parliament, has lunch with Lady Bruton and Hugh Whitbread. He plans to tell Clarissa that he loves her, but struggles to find the words. On his way home, he buys a bouquet of roses for her. He returns to find Clarissa resting and gives her the flowers, but still cannot articulate his deeper feelings.

Later in the afternoon, Peter Walsh sees Clarissa's daughter, Elizabeth, with her history tutor, Miss Kilman. Miss Kilman is a devout Christian who resents Clarissa's worldly lifestyle and attempts to convert Elizabeth to her own religious views, fostering a strong, almost possessive attachment to the girl. Elizabeth, feeling stifled by Miss Kilman, eventually escapes to ride a bus and enjoy a moment of independence, contemplating a future career.

Septimus and Rezia are at home, trying to cope with the impending institutionalization. Dr. Holmes, Septimus's general practitioner, arrives for another visit, despite Septimus's intense fear and hatred of him. Septimus, feeling cornered and desperate to protect his inner self from the doctors' intrusions, sees no escape. As Dr. Holmes and Rezia try to reach him, Septimus, in a final act of defiance and a desperate attempt to preserve his soul, jumps from the window of their apartment, falling to his death on the railings below. Rezia is left alone with his body.

In the evening, Clarissa's party begins. Guests arrive, including Lady Bruton, Hugh Whitbread, and eventually Peter Walsh. Clarissa moves among her guests, ensuring everyone is comfortable, feeling the success of her party but also a sense of detachment and the superficiality of social interactions. Sally Seton, Clarissa's old friend from Bourton, now Lady Rosseter, also arrives, and she and Peter reminisce about their shared youth and Clarissa. The Prime Minister makes a brief appearance, causing a stir among the guests.

Late in the evening, Sir William Bradshaw and Lady Bradshaw arrive at the party. They discreetly mention to Clarissa the "unfortunate incident" – the suicide of their patient, Septimus Warren Smith, earlier that day. Clarissa is profoundly disturbed by the news. She retreats to a small, quiet room, reflecting on Septimus's death. She feels a deep, unexpected connection to his despair and his final act, understanding it as a desperate assertion of self against an oppressive world. She sees his death as a part of her own life, a sacrifice, and a protest against the forces that seek to control and diminish the individual spirit.

Clarissa eventually returns to her guests, profoundly changed by the news. Peter Walsh sees her across the room, feeling the familiar, intense presence that has always drawn him to her. The party continues, but Clarissa's experience of the evening has been irrevocably altered by the tragedy that has indirectly touched her world. The novel concludes with Peter's perception of Clarissa, "For there she was."

summary_llm:
Here is a very detailed summary of the plot for Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice":

The story opens in the rural English village of Longbourn, focusing on the Bennet family. Mrs. Bennet's sole ambition in life is to see her five daughters—Jane, Elizabeth, Mary, Kitty, and Lydia—married off to wealthy men. Her hopes are ignited by the news that a rich, single young man named Mr. Charles Bingley has rented the nearby estate of Netherfield Park.

Mr. Bingley soon arrives, accompanied by his two sisters, Miss Caroline Bingley and Mrs. Louisa Hurst, and his very wealthy, proud, and aristocratic friend, Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy. At the first public assembly ball in Meryton, Bingley is immediately charmed by the eldest Bennet daughter, the beautiful and sweet-natured Jane, dancing with her twice. However, Mr. Darcy offends Elizabeth Bennet, the second eldest, by refusing to dance with her and remarking that she is "tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me." Elizabeth, proud and quick-witted, immediately takes a strong dislike to him, thus setting the stage for their "pride and prejudice."

Over the following weeks, Bingley and Jane's affection for each other grows. Jane visits Netherfield and falls ill, leading Elizabeth to walk three miles through muddy fields to care for her. During this stay, Elizabeth frequently clashes with Darcy, who, despite his initial disdain, finds himself increasingly drawn to her intelligence and lively spirit, much to the annoyance of Caroline Bingley, who harbors her own designs on Darcy.

The Bennet family is then visited by Mr. William Collins, a pompous and obsequious clergyman who is the entailed heir to their estate, meaning he will inherit Longbourn upon Mr. Bennet's death. Mr. Collins, advised by his patroness Lady Catherine de Bourgh (who is also Mr. Darcy's aunt), intends to marry one of the Bennet daughters to make amends for disinheriting them. He first sets his sights on Jane, but Mrs. Bennet redirects him to Elizabeth.

During this period, the local militia arrives in Meryton, bringing with it a charming and handsome officer named Mr. George Wickham. Wickham quickly befriends Elizabeth and, upon learning of her dislike for Darcy, tells her a fabricated story about how Darcy cruelly denied him an inheritance and a living that was rightfully his, left by Darcy's late father. Elizabeth, already prejudiced against Darcy, readily believes Wickham and her dislike for Darcy intensifies.

Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, delivering a long, self-important speech about his reasons. Elizabeth, finding him insufferable, firmly rejects him, much to her mother's fury and her father's relief. Shortly after, Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth's sensible and practical friend, Charlotte Lucas, who, at 27 and fearing spinsterhood, accepts him for the security and comfortable home he can offer, despite not loving him. Elizabeth is shocked but understands Charlotte's pragmatic decision.

The Netherfield party abruptly departs for London, leaving Jane heartbroken and confused. Caroline Bingley sends a letter to Jane, implying that Bingley will marry Darcy's sister, Georgiana, and that Bingley's sisters disapprove of Jane. Elizabeth is convinced that Darcy and Bingley's sisters conspired to separate Jane and Bingley.

Elizabeth later goes to visit Charlotte and Mr. Collins at their parsonage in Hunsford, Kent, which is adjacent to Lady Catherine de Bourgh's grand estate, Rosings Park. During her stay, Mr. Darcy, along with his cousin Colonel Fitzwilliam, arrives to visit his aunt, Lady Catherine. Darcy and Elizabeth frequently encounter each other, and Darcy's behavior towards her seems to soften.

Unexpectedly, Darcy proposes to Elizabeth, expressing his love but also dwelling on her social inferiority and the vulgarity of her family. Elizabeth is outraged and rejects him vehemently, accusing him of being arrogant, of ruining Jane's happiness, and of mistreating Wickham.

The next day, Darcy intercepts Elizabeth during her walk and hands her a long letter. In it, he addresses her accusations. He explains that he separated Jane and Bingley because he genuinely believed Jane did not return Bingley's affection with equal intensity, and he also expressed concern about the impropriety of her family. Regarding Wickham, Darcy reveals the truth: Wickham squandered his inheritance, attempted to extort more money from Darcy, and later tried to elope with Darcy's fifteen-year-old sister, Georgiana, to gain her fortune.

Elizabeth is stunned by the revelations. She rereads the letter multiple times, gradually realizing the truth of Darcy's account and the extent of Wickham's deceit. She feels ashamed of her own blind prejudice and her misjudgment of both men.

Upon returning home, Elizabeth finds that Wickham's regiment is leaving Meryton, and her youngest sister, Lydia, has been invited to Brighton with a friend, Mrs. Forster, the wife of the colonel. Lydia, a frivolous and flirtatious girl, is excited by the prospect of more officers.

Later, Elizabeth embarks on a tour of the Peak District with her aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner. They decide to visit Pemberley, Darcy's magnificent estate, believing he is away. To their surprise, they encounter Darcy himself, who has returned unexpectedly. Darcy's demeanor is entirely changed; he is polite, welcoming, and hospitable, treating Elizabeth and the Gardiners with utmost respect. He introduces Elizabeth to his sister, Georgiana, who is shy but amiable. Elizabeth is deeply impressed by Darcy's character, his estate, and the high regard in which he is held by his servants. She begins to see him in a completely new light, recognizing his true goodness.

However, their pleasant visit is cut short by urgent letters from Longbourn: Lydia has eloped with Wickham. The family is in disgrace, and it is feared that Wickham has no intention of marrying her. Elizabeth confides in Darcy, who is visibly distressed by the news. Elizabeth and the Gardiners immediately return home.

The Bennet family is plunged into despair. Mr. Bennet and Mr. Gardiner search for Lydia and Wickham in London. Eventually, Mr. Gardiner sends word that Wickham has agreed to marry Lydia, provided he receives a small sum of money and a commission in the army. The family believes Mr. Gardiner paid Wickham off, and they are immensely relieved, though the terms are still humiliating.

After Lydia and Wickham are married and visit Longbourn, Lydia carelessly reveals to Elizabeth that Mr. Darcy was present at her wedding and was instrumental in arranging it. Elizabeth writes to Mrs. Gardiner, who confirms the shocking truth: Darcy had found Lydia and Wickham, paid off Wickham's enormous debts, bought him a commission, and secured their marriage, all to protect the Bennet family's reputation and out of concern for Elizabeth. Elizabeth is overwhelmed by Darcy's selfless generosity and realizes the depth of his love for her.

Soon after, Mr. Bingley returns to Netherfield, accompanied by Darcy. Bingley, having been informed by Darcy of Jane's true affections, proposes to Jane, who happily accepts.

A few days later, Lady Catherine de Bourgh unexpectedly arrives at Longbourn, having heard rumors that Elizabeth is to marry Darcy. She imperiously demands that Elizabeth promise never to marry her nephew, considering Elizabeth an unsuitable match due to her inferior connections. Elizabeth firmly refuses, asserting her independence and right to choose. This defiance, ironically, gives Darcy hope that Elizabeth's feelings for him have changed.

Darcy soon proposes to Elizabeth again, this time humbly, acknowledging his past pride and expressing his enduring love. Elizabeth, now fully aware of his true character and her own love for him, joyfully accepts.

Mr. Bennet is initially skeptical, fearing Elizabeth does not truly love Darcy, but is convinced by her earnest assurances. Mrs. Bennet is ecstatic at the prospect of her daughter marrying such a wealthy and well-connected man.

The story concludes with the marriages of Elizabeth and Darcy, and Jane and Bingley. Lydia and Wickham remain a burden, but are largely ignored by the family. Lady Catherine eventually reconciles with Darcy, though grudgingly. Elizabeth and Georgiana Darcy become close friends, and the Gardiners are forever cherished by Elizabeth for their role in bringing her and Darcy together. Elizabeth and Darcy settle at Pemberley, finding happiness in a marriage founded on mutual respect, understanding, and love, having overcome their initial pride and prejudice.

summary_llm:
Robinson Crusoe, born in York in 1632, recounts his life story, beginning with his early defiance of his father's wishes. His father, a prosperous merchant, intended for him to pursue a career in law and live a comfortable middle-class life. However, Robinson possesses an insatiable desire for adventure and a life at sea, against his father's strong warnings about the dangers and potential miseries.

At the age of 19, Robinson disobeys his parents and embarks on his first voyage from Hull to London with a friend. A violent storm nearly sinks the ship, filling him with guilt and fear, but these feelings soon dissipate. His second voyage takes him to Guinea, but his ship is captured by Turkish pirates (Sallee rovers). He is enslaved by a Moorish captain for two years, enduring a harsh existence.

During a fishing trip, Robinson manages to escape with a young Moorish boy named Xury. They sail south along the African coast in a small boat, facing dangers from wild animals and other natives. Eventually, they are rescued by a Portuguese captain bound for Brazil. Robinson sells Xury to the captain (with the condition that Xury would be freed in ten years if he converted to Christianity) and settles in Brazil. He uses the money from the sale and a small amount from his English family to buy land and establish a successful sugar plantation. After several years, he becomes a prosperous planter but faces a shortage of labor.

Driven by his ambition and the need for more workers, Robinson agrees to join an illegal slave-trading voyage to Africa to procure slaves for himself and his fellow planters. This proves to be his undoing. The ship encounters a terrible storm near the Orinoco River. The vessel is wrecked, and Robinson is the sole survivor, washed ashore on a deserted island on September 30, 1659.

His initial days are marked by despair and resourcefulness. He spends his first night in a tree, fearing wild beasts. The next day, he discovers the ship is still partially intact. Over several days, he makes multiple trips to the wreck, salvaging tools, weapons, food, clothes, sails, ropes, timber, and other essential supplies before the ship breaks up completely and sinks. He builds a fortified habitation – a cave and tent behind a strong palisade – on a hill overlooking the sea, providing protection and a vantage point. He keeps a journal, meticulously detailing his daily activities and thoughts (until his ink runs out), and marks the passage of time by notching a large post.

Robinson explores the island, discovering wild goats, which he eventually domesticates for milk and meat. He finds barley and rice growing from spilled seeds and learns to cultivate them, eventually baking his own bread after many failures. He also learns to make pottery. He suffers a severe fever and ague, during which he finds religious solace and repentance, reflecting on his past disobedience. He rescues a parrot, which he teaches to speak. He builds a large canoe, but it's too heavy to launch, leading him to construct a smaller, more manageable one later. He discovers a fertile "country estate" on the other side of the island, where he builds a second, more secluded shelter.

After 15 years of solitude, Robinson makes a terrifying discovery: a single human footprint on the beach. Later, he finds human bones, skulls, and other remains, confirming the presence of cannibalistic natives who occasionally visit the island for their feasts. He lives in constant fear, reinforcing his fortifications and developing plans to ambush the cannibals, but he ultimately reconsiders, deciding it is not his place to judge or punish them.

Years later, after 23 years on the island, Robinson witnesses a large group of cannibals arrive with two prisoners. One prisoner escapes and runs towards Robinson's habitation. Robinson intervenes, shooting some of the cannibals and saving the man. He names him Friday, after the day of the week he was rescued. Robinson teaches Friday English and Christianity, and Friday becomes his loyal and devoted servant. Friday reveals that his people sometimes save prisoners and that there are other white men (Spaniards) shipwrecked on a nearby island.

Another group of cannibals arrives with three prisoners. Robinson and Friday attack, saving two of them. To Robinson's astonishment and joy, one of the rescued prisoners is Friday's father, and the other is a Spaniard. They learn that the Spaniard and his companions (16 of them) are indeed shipwrecked on a nearby island. Robinson plans to send Friday's father and the Spaniard back to the other island to bring the other Spaniards to help him build a larger boat for their escape. They depart, promising to return.

Before they can return, an English ship appears. Robinson is overjoyed, believing his rescue has finally come. However, he soon realizes it is a mutiny. Three prisoners are brought ashore by the mutineers. Robinson and Friday ambush the mutineers, rescuing the English captain and his two loyal officers. They learn that the mutineers plan to abandon the captain and take the ship, which is bound for Brazil. Robinson, Friday, the captain, and his officers devise a plan. They successfully kill or capture the remaining mutineers, regaining control of the ship. Robinson, pretending to be the island's governor, makes the mutineers believe the island is inhabited by a large force, further aiding their deception.

Robinson prepares to leave his island, which he has inhabited for 28 years, 2 months, and 19 days. He gives his "kingdom" to the remaining mutineers who chose to stay, along with the two rescued Spaniards (who have returned with Friday's father and the other Spaniards), instructing them on how to live and govern themselves.

He departs on December 19, 1686, and arrives in England on June 11, 1687. He discovers that his parents have died. Traveling to Lisbon, he finds that his Brazilian plantation has been well-managed by a trustee and has made him a very wealthy man. He sells his plantation and, fearing another sea voyage, travels back to England by land through Spain and France, encountering various dangers, including wolves in the Pyrenees. He eventually settles down, marries, and has three children, though his wife later dies. Robinson Crusoe concludes his narrative by reflecting on his extraordinary adventures and his newfound prosperity, mentioning that he later revisited his island, but the details of that journey are reserved for a future account.

book_title: Six Characters in Search of an Author-Luigi Pirandello
summary_llm:
The play opens on a bare stage, with the curtain already up, revealing the set for a play that is about to be rehearsed. Stagehands are moving props and scenery. The Director (also referred to as the Manager) enters, expressing his annoyance with the state of modern theatre and the play they are about to rehearse, which is one of Pirandello's own, "Mixing It Up" (or "The Rules of the Game" in some translations). The Acting Company, including the Leading Actor, Leading Actress, Second Actress, and Prompter, gradually arrives, complaining about the Director's demands and the play itself.

As the rehearsal is about to begin, six figures, dressed in dark mourning clothes, appear from the back of the auditorium and slowly make their way onto the stage. These are the Six Characters: the Father, the Mother, the Step-Daughter, the Son, the Boy, and the Little Girl. The Director and his actors are bewildered and annoyed by this interruption, assuming they are either madmen or a prank.

The Father, acting as their spokesperson, explains their predicament: they are characters abandoned by their author, who conceived their drama but failed to write it. They have come to the theatre in search of a new author, or rather, a company of actors, to give their unwritten story life on stage. The Director initially dismisses them, but the Father passionately argues for their reality, claiming they are more real than the actors because their existence is fixed and unchanging within their drama, unlike the fleeting reality of human beings.

Intrigued by the novelty and potential for a unique theatrical experience, the Director agrees to listen to their story. The Characters begin to reveal their tragic family history.

The Father explains that he, an intellectual, had sent his wife (the Mother) away years ago to live with his secretary, believing they were better suited to each other. The Mother then had three children with the secretary: the Step-Daughter, the Boy, and the Little Girl. The Son, the Father's legitimate child, expresses his utter disdain for the entire situation and his family, remaining aloof and refusing to participate in the recounting of their drama. The Mother, dressed in black and constantly weeping, is a figure of profound sorrow and rarely speaks, her grief expressed through her actions. The Step-Daughter, bold and defiant, frequently interrupts the Father, offering her own bitter and accusatory version of events.

The Director, seeing the dramatic potential, decides to let the Characters act out their story for his company to observe and then attempt to perform. He orders a rough set to be prepared for the first scene: Madame Pace's dressmaking shop.

The Characters begin to perform the scene. The Step-Daughter, after her stepfather's death, had been forced into poverty with her Mother and younger siblings. To support them, she works for Madame Pace, who runs a dressmaking shop that is also a discreet brothel. Madame Pace herself materializes from the back room, a grotesque figure conjured into existence by the Characters' need for her in their drama. The Father, unaware that the Step-Daughter is working there, enters Madame Pace's establishment seeking "diversion." He is about to engage in an intimate act with the Step-Daughter when the Mother, who has followed the Father, bursts in, screaming in horror and revealing the Step-Daughter's identity to the Father. The Father is overcome with shame and disgust.

The Characters perform this scene with intense, raw emotion, much to the astonishment of the Acting Company. The Director then stops them and asks his actors to try and imitate the scene. The actors' performance, however, is artificial and lacks the Characters' genuine pain and passion. The Characters are disgusted by the actors' inability to capture their truth. The Step-Daughter mocks the actress playing her, exaggerating her gestures, while the Father tries to explain the complex psychological nuances of his feelings, which the actors cannot grasp. The Director tries to mediate, explaining that theatre requires simplification and stylization, but the Characters insist on the absolute truth of their drama.

The Director, still determined, moves on to the next part of their story: the family's return to the Father's house after the Madame Pace incident. The Son, still resentful, is forced to recount his perspective: his disgust at seeing the Mother, Step-Daughter, Boy, and Little Girl enter his "pure" home, disrupting his solitude and his sense of order. The Father attempts to justify his actions, claiming he took them in out of a sense of duty and remorse, but the Son sees it as a further defilement.

The climax of the Characters' drama unfolds in the garden of the Father's house. The Mother recounts the tragic fate of her two youngest children. The Little Girl is playing innocently by a fountain in the garden. The Boy, withdrawn and silent throughout the play, hides behind a tree, unnoticed by the others. Suddenly, a shot rings out. The Boy has shot himself with a revolver. Simultaneously, the Little Girl, startled by the noise, falls into the fountain and drowns.

The Mother screams in agony, rushing to her children. The Step-Daughter, horrified, runs first to the Boy, then to the Little Girl. The Director and the actors are thrown into chaos and confusion, unable to discern whether these deaths are "real" within the context of the Characters' drama or if actual tragedy has occurred on their stage. The Father insists that it is all part of their unchangeable reality.

Amidst the pandemonium, the Step-Daughter, with a final, hysterical laugh, runs off the stage and disappears into the darkness. The Mother is left weeping inconsolably over the bodies of her children. The Son remains cold and detached, confirming his complete alienation.

Overwhelmed and utterly bewildered by the uncontrollable nature of the Characters' drama, the Director declares the rehearsal over. He cannot proceed with such a chaotic and disturbing "play" where the line between theatrical illusion and reality has completely dissolved. The remaining Characters – the Father, the Mother, and the Son – slowly disappear into the darkness, leaving the stage empty.

The actors are left shaken, some believing they have witnessed a real tragedy, others dismissing it as a theatrical trick. The Director, exasperated and feeling he has wasted a day on a "mad" and unstageable experience, orders the lights out and the stage cleared, concluding the play in a state of unresolved confusion and theatrical collapse.

The Father explains they seek an author, the Manager dismisses them as "madmen," and the Father argues about the absurdity of life versus the "madness of acting."

**3. Family History and Dynamics:**
*   **Original:** States Father proper once had a clerk who befriended Mother. Seeing "mute appeal," he sent her off with him and took her Son (his legitimate son). The Mother's lover (the clerk) was the father of "her, the Child, and Boy." After the clerk died, the family fell into poverty.

Manager interrupts, calls Leading Man/Lady to play scene. Father protests, Step-Daughter laughs. Manager complains about author present. Step-Daughter refuses "romantic sentimental scene," offers scene as it truly was.

Actors try to imitate, fail, Characters are disgusted, Step-Daughter mocks, Father explains nuances. Director mediates, Characters insist on truth.
*   **Justification:**
    *   **Extra:** The description of Pace as a "grotesque figure conjured into existence by the Characters' need for her in their drama" is an interpretive addition.
    *   **Missing:** Many specific details and lines from the original are omitted: the Leading Lady's "vulgar trick" comment, Father's philosophical point about the "magic of the stage," Pace's specific line, the actors' laughter at her accent, the Manager finding it "magnificent," Father offering Step-Daughter a hat, her refusal, the Manager calling actors to play the scene, Father protesting, Step-Daughter laughing, and the Manager complaining about the author's presence. The Step-Daughter's refusal to let them compose a "romantic sentimental scene" and her insistence on the scene as it truly was is captured in essence but not with the same detail.

**6. Father's Philosophy and Son's Perspective:**
*   **Original:** Father bristles at "illusion," approaches Manager, asks "who he really is." Explains a character can always pose this question to a man as he is always somebody while a man might be nobody, and a character's reality is immutable. Manager commands Father to stop philosophizing, imitating an author he detests. Son objects to living before a mirror that "freezes us... throws likeness back... horrible grimace." *   **Original:** Son saw the drowning Child in the fountain, and the Boy standing stock still watching her. A shot rings out from behind the trees where the Boy is hidden. Father insists on unchangeable reality. Step-Daughter, with a "final, hysterical laugh," runs off. Mother weeps. Son cold. Director declares rehearsal over, cannot proceed, line between illusion/reality dissolved. Remaining Characters disappear. Actors shaken. Director exasperated, wasted day.

However, it contains a significant factual error regarding the family's backstory (the "secretary" and the parentage of the children), completely omits a crucial scene (Step-Daughter with the revolver after the break), and introduces interpretive causal links and character actions (simultaneous deaths, characters disappearing) not explicitly stated in the original. These issues go beyond minor discrepancies and impact the accuracy of the summary.

book_title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn-Mark Twain
summary_llm:
Here is a very detailed summary of the plot for Mark Twain's "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn":

The story begins with Huckleberry "Huck" Finn, a young boy living in St. Petersburg, Missouri, after the events of "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer." He has been "adopted" by the kind but strict Widow Douglas and her sister, Miss Watson, who are attempting to "sivilize" him by teaching him manners, religion, and proper behavior. Huck finds this life stifling and longs for his old, free ways. He has a substantial sum of money, found with Tom Sawyer, which the Widow Douglas is holding in trust for him.

Huck's estranged, abusive, and perpetually drunk father, Pap Finn, suddenly reappears. Pap, a racist and violent man, is furious that Huck is becoming educated and has money. He demands Huck's money, but Judge Thatcher, who is managing Huck's funds, refuses to give it to him. Pap eventually kidnaps Huck, taking him to a secluded cabin in the Illinois woods across the river. He locks Huck in the cabin, beats him regularly, and frequently leaves him alone for days while he goes off to drink.

Tired of the abuse and confinement, Huck meticulously plans his escape. He fakes his own murder by killing a wild pig, scattering its blood around the cabin, and leaving a trail of cornmeal and an axe to suggest robbers broke in and killed him. He then escapes by canoe down the Mississippi River to Jackson's Island.

On Jackson's Island, Huck discovers Miss Watson's slave, Jim, hiding. Jim reveals he has run away because he overheard Miss Watson planning to sell him downriver to New Orleans, separating him from his family. Huck and Jim form an unlikely bond, both being fugitives from society. They find a two-story house floating down the river during a flood; they salvage useful items, but Jim prevents Huck from looking at a dead man inside, claiming it's too ghastly.

After a few days, Huck, disguised as a girl named "Sarah Williams," goes ashore to a nearby town to gather information. He meets Mrs. Judith Loftus, who tells him that Jim is suspected of Huck's murder, and there's a reward out for him. She also mentions that some people suspect Pap Finn, but Jim is the main target. Mrs. Loftus quickly sees through Huck's disguise by testing him with a needle and thread and by observing how he throws. She is kind to him but confirms that her husband plans to search Jackson's Island that very night. Huck rushes back to warn Jim, and they quickly pack their raft and escape further downriver.

Their journey down the Mississippi becomes central to the plot. They encounter a wrecked steamboat, the *Walter Scott*, and overhear two robbers planning to murder a third. Huck, feeling a pang of conscience, tries to get help for the robbers, but their raft drifts away, leaving the criminals to their fate. They salvage some loot from the wreck.

A thick fog causes them to miss Cairo, Illinois, their intended destination where Jim hoped to reach free states. A large steamboat then crashes into their raft, separating Huck and Jim. Huck believes Jim is dead.

Huck is taken in by the Grangerfords, a wealthy, aristocratic family. He becomes friends with Buck Grangerford, a boy his age. Huck soon learns that the Grangerfords are locked in a generations-long, violent feud with another local family, the Shepherdsons. The feud is so old that no one remembers its original cause. The conflict escalates when Sophia Grangerford elopes with Harney Shepherdson. This triggers a brutal shootout where Buck and other Grangerford men are killed. Horrified, Huck finds Jim, who had been hiding nearby with the raft, and they quickly escape back to the river.

Soon after, Huck and Jim pick up two con artists who claim to be a deposed French duke (the "Duke of Bilgewater") and the rightful King of France (the "Dauphin" or "King Louis XVII"). These two charlatans quickly take over the raft and begin devising schemes to swindle money from unsuspecting townspeople.

Their first stop involves a drunken man named Boggs, who is publicly shamed and then shot dead by Colonel Sherburn. A mob attempts to lynch Sherburn, but he bravely confronts and disperses them with a powerful speech about their cowardice. The Duke and King then perform a crude, short play called "The Royal Nonesuch," which is a scam designed to trick people into paying to see a performance that lasts only a few minutes. They repeat this trick in several towns, always leaving before the audience realizes they've been duped.

Their most elaborate scheme involves the recently deceased Peter Wilks. The Duke and King impersonate Wilks's long-lost English brothers, Harvey and William, who are expected to inherit his fortune. They convincingly fool the Wilks's three orphaned daughters, Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna, and the entire town. Huck, witnessing their cruel deception and seeing the genuine grief of the Wilks sisters, feels immense guilt. He decides to expose the con artists. He secretly steals the inherited gold from the Duke and King and hides it in Peter Wilks's coffin.

The real Wilks brothers eventually arrive, leading to a chaotic scene where the imposters are nearly exposed. A handwriting test and a search for a tattoo on the deceased Peter Wilks fail to definitively identify the true heirs. In the confusion, Huck manages to escape, but the Duke and King also manage to get away and catch up with him and Jim on the raft.

Later, in a moment of spite, the King sells Jim to a local farmer, Silas Phelps, for forty dollars, claiming Jim is a runaway from New Orleans. This act deeply distresses Huck. He struggles with his conscience, believing that helping a runaway slave is a sin that will send him to hell. However, after much internal turmoil, he decides to "go to hell" and free Jim, tearing up a letter he had written to Miss Watson revealing Jim's whereabouts.

Huck arrives at the Phelps farm and is immediately mistaken for Tom Sawyer, Silas Phelps's nephew, who is expected for a visit. Huck plays along. When the real Tom Sawyer arrives, Huck intercepts him and explains the situation. Tom, instead of simply helping Jim escape, devises an elaborate, romanticized, and utterly impractical plan based on his adventure novels. He pretends to be his own brother, Sid Sawyer.

Tom's "evasion" plan involves digging a tunnel with knives (which they eventually switch to pickaxes), writing anonymous warning letters, making Jim keep a journal on a shirt, having Jim tame rats and snakes, sawing off a bedpost, and other absurdities, all to make the escape more "grand" and adventurous. Jim patiently endures these antics.

The overly complicated escape plan finally culminates in a chaotic scene. The Phelps family and their neighbors, alerted by Tom's anonymous letters, ambush the shed where Jim is held. Jim, Huck, and Tom escape, but Tom is shot in the leg. Jim, despite being a free man if he were to continue running, insists on staying with the wounded Tom, risking his own freedom to help get a doctor. Huck goes for a doctor, and Jim is recaptured and brought back to the Phelps farm.

Aunt Sally and Uncle Silas are furious with Jim and the "boys." However, Tom, recovering from his wound, reveals the truth: Miss Watson died two months prior and freed Jim in her will. Aunt Polly, Tom's real aunt, then arrives, confirming Tom's story and exposing Huck's and Tom's true identities.

Jim is officially a free man. He then reveals to Huck that the dead man in the floating house back on Jackson's Island was Pap Finn, meaning Huck is no longer under his father's control.

At the end of the story, Aunt Sally offers to adopt Huck and "sivilize" him again. But Huck, having experienced enough of society's rules and hypocrisy, decides he's had enough of being "sivilized" and plans to "light out for the Territory" (the American West) to escape further attempts to tame him.
